abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, and unlikely sustainability, with modest
            institutional development impacts. Likewise, both the Bank
            and Borrower performances were unsatisfactory. Several
            lessons outline the following. The experience with the
            Project shows that leaving behind the definition of the
            baseline data, and of a realistic set of (targets)
            monitoring and evaluation based on performance indicators,
            the actual project implementation becomes highly risky. The
            planned baseline survey was not carried out, making not only
            the evaluation of the Project very difficult, but also
            deprived Project management in the Government, and the Bank
            of an important tool, which could have had the required
            corrective action. Moreover, this experience reinforces that
            to achieve success, concerted efforts to engage key members
            of the Government, the executing agency, and the targeted
            communities, should be established at the earliest stages of
            Project preparation. This will also align Project
            interventions to existing programs, familiar to those
            actors, since even a well designed Project, if implemented
            in isolation, faces the high risk of not succeeding in
            reaching its objectives. Further lessons suggest that
            training, and retraining strategies need to be part of a
            staff development system that considers not only the skill
            needs by level, but also the adequate methodologies to
            transmit such skills to different types and levels of
            personnel, which includes on the job-training; and,
            implementation arrangements need to be carefully tailored to
            the institutional capacity of the country, closely monitored
            during Project implementation.
